We will also learn the process of generating and implementing unique and world changing ideas through different inspiring stories of creative, innovative and successful people ever lived on this world.
courseTitle: Creativity and Innovation: How to think like a genius 2.0

courseDescription: Still struggling with your college applications? Haven’t finished your personal statement? How about your supplements? Do you know where to start? If you answered no to any of the previous questions, this course was made just for you! The main objective of this seminar is to supply you with the essential strategies and knowledge that will help you create effective and successful college essays for your application. We will also be discussing aspects of the application that are commonly overlooked by students, such as the waitlist process, admissions interviews, and other parts of the Common Application. We'll be offering one-on-one feedback to cater directly to any questions or concerns you may have.
courseTitle: College Process 101: 2 Months until the Deadline

courseDescription: What pushes a car down the road?  Why does a compass point North?  Does my watch always tick as fast as yours?  Why do we care whether Schrodinger’s cat is dead or alive?  These questions -- and many, many more -- occupy the minds of researchers and students of Physics all around the globe every single day.  In this course, we will endeavor to equip you with the theoretical tools to start investigating such questions on your own.  Across nine class sessions, we will offer a cursory introduction to the major subjects that every undergraduate Physics student encounters: Mechanics, Electricity & Magnetism, Relativity, Quantum Mechanics, & Thermodynamics.  Though each subject requires at least a lifetime of mathematical study to truly “master” (if mastery can be spoken of in research science…), a conceptual introduction with a little bit of (hopefully) familiar mathematics will not only prepare students for the possibility of further study, but will also teach students how physicists organize and think through a physical problem.  Even if you have no intention to pursue Physics in college and beyond, the physicist’s practice of questioning and problem solving is an invaluable skill to carry into any profession or field of study.  Plus, you may just pick up a few fun party facts along the way.
courseTitle: Physics 101: A Guide to Physical Phenomena

courseDescription: The Gordian Knot, an ancient puzzle that marked a legendary chapter of Alexander the Great, has become the term used to describe complex and unsolvable problems. In life there is no doubt that problems exist all over the place. From the most complicated questions such as trying to prove the Riemann Hypothesis or discussing the meaning of life, to the more mundane problems such as trying to open a jar or simply figuring out what you're gonna eat for the night, the solution may not always be easy to find. In this course, we will be exploring a variety of problem solving methods while looking over a myriad of complicated problems that exists around the world.
courseTitle: Problem Solving: Unraveling the Gordian Knot

courseDescription: From Cauchy's Functional Equation and the Pigeonhole Principle to the Chicken McNugget Theorem, in this seminar you'll learn almost anything you need to prepare for math olympiads. We’ll start by introducing basic proof techniques and then dive into the main four areas of competitive mathematics: Algebra, Number Theory, Geometry and Combinatorics. We'll be talking about theorems, techniques, along with some cool tricks for solving math olympiad problems. The class will include discussion of solutions of problems in the topics covered. All in all, you’ll gain a solid understanding of olympiad mathematics and learn the key to success in math competitions.

Are you stressed about college applications? Do you find yourself worrying constantly that you’re not qualified to get into your dream school? Are you wondering how on earth you’re going to condense your life’s work and achievements (or the lack thereof) into an application essay? Well if you answered “yes” to any of these questions we are here to help you! College application season is upon us and with the ongoing global pandemic, we understand that it’s harder than normal to connect with resources to help you perfect your applications. Through this course, our goal is to make each and every one of you an expert at marketing your skillsets and thoroughly prepare you for the college application process whether you’re using UC, common, or coalition applications. Our diverse team of instructors is ready to answer any questions you may have whether you’re planning on going to community college and transferring, wondering the difference between a public and private education, thinking about going out of state, or are first-gen and have no idea where to start. See you in class!
courseTitle: Looking Cool for College: Tackling Admissions Essays

courseDescription: This class will be a hands on learning experience in early stage startup formation. We start from scratch with brainstorming problems and solutions, then learn how to prototype our solution and test with potential consumers - crucial skills for any entrepreneur!

This class on Game Theory will cover many of the key topics to start off the subject, such as simultaneous games, Mixed-Nash equilibria, auctions, and voting. Game Theory has many applications in our world, especially in economics, electronic commerce, politics and strategy, sports, and good old-fashioned game playing. Participants should have an advanced knowledge of Algebra.

You may know a fair share of artists -- Michelangelo, Picasso, Monet, Van Gogh… But how many female artists can you name off the top of your head? The answer is: NOT ENOUGH! Traditional art history has ignored the work of female artists, therefore our cultural understanding of artistic genius is overwhelmingly male (despite the arts being long-associated with femininity). Women artists have always existed, yet they were either ignored or not credited as serious innovators. In this workshop you will definitely hear some facts to trigger your feminist consciousness, but most importantly you will leave feeling inspired and knowing the names/artwork of LOTS of female artists throughout history.
courseTitle: Know Their Names: Female Artists Throughout History

courseDescription: Assassinations, Vietnam, protests, crackdowns, and a political party realignment: all of these marked 1968 as a watershed moment in American history. This course will examine several major events of the year through a combination of lectures, readings of primary source documents, and guided discussions. By the end, students will understand the significance of this monumental year, and how it continues to shape our culture and politics today. Anyone with an interest in developing their skill of critical historical thinking is encouraged to apply.
prereqs: Some basic level of US history course

courseDescription: Coming soon!
Explore important fields of mathematics such as probability, combinatorics, and geometry through their applications to burritos, enchiladas, and other tasty adventures!
courseTitle: The Mathematics of Burritos, Enchiladas, and more!

courseDescription: The phrase 'public health' has been rising in prevalence within the past year, but what exactly does it mean? Beyond COVID-19, public health is a field that encompasses a myriad of topics— maternal health, epidemiology, racial disparities, international populations, vaccine distribution, and more! Each session, we will be exploring a new handful of topics and their importance to public health. We will also be looking at public health on individual, community, and national scales. Come find out what aspects interest YOU the most for a future career or just browse to learn a little more about this increasingly important discipline!
courseTitle: Exploring Public Health: What Is It Exactly and Where Do I Fit In?

courseDescription: Want to learn how to pursue a career in sustainability? Want to create a project that benefits your community? At "Paths to Sustainability," we'll teach you the basics of sustainability, have professors and people from diverse career fields come in to share their stories on how they incorporate sustainability in their roles, and finally, you'll be paired up in teams to solve issues in your community!

Love animated films? Curious to know how filters actually work? In this course, we'll answer these questions, and more! From the tools and mechanisms of digital art to the foundations of lighting and shape techniques of art, you'll learn how to use free, phone-friendly apps to create your own drawings, comics, and even animations. The program we will use is Ibispaint X, which is free for iPad, iPhone, other touch screen devices, and the computer. At the end of this program, students will have knowledge on how to use them and apply traditional art techniques onto a digital setting. Get ready to color your screen!

Have you ever had a moment where you wanted to draw something but felt you didn’t have the “artistic talent” to do so? Well, scroll no further. This course will cover the basics of drawing still life, a medium undervalued by many, but catalyzes many artistic endeavours. You will learn the basics of the medium, perspective, value, untold tips and tricks and have the opportunity to create your own still life drawing by the end of the course. Upon completing this course, you will no longer see the world the same way as you did before. All you need is a pencil, paper and a positive attitude!

Cultural competence is essential to the way we relate to one another, in both the professional world and our personal friendships. In this course, we will define culture and discuss how it relates to our mental health experiences. Together, we'll brainstorm strategies to overcome racial barriers to mental health resources and create resources for our own communities! As we discuss and unpack mental health topics from racial trauma, to erasure, to resilience, we will raise up forgotten voices to build a future where we help people better, together. ***Content warning: While I strive to make this course as engaging and uplifting as possible, we will discuss heavy topics such as racism, trauma, mental illness, and suicide. There will not be graphic images or descriptions of violence or suffering, but these topics may still be uncomfortable to engage with, so I would strongly encourage you to keep this in mind. Content and trigger warnings will be used throughout each session.
courseTitle: A Culturally Competent Guide to Mental Health

courseDescription: What comes to your mind when you think of a nurse? Is it the image of your school nurse taking your weight and height? Or is it the thought of a bedside caregiver in a hospital? Chances are that if these are the only things you think nurses do, you don’t actually know what the nursing profession is all about! Did you know that you can even travel around the world as a nurse? In this course, I will teach you all about nursing, from the misconceptions of nursing to all the career opportunities you can pursue as a nurse! If I have convinced you to become a nurse, I am going to provide you a step-by-step path to pursue this profession, starting now as a high schooler!
courseTitle: What is Nursing?: A Comprehensive Guide for High Schoolers

At "Paths to Sustainability," we'll teach you the basics of sustainability, have professors and people from diverse career fields come in to share their stories on how they incorporate sustainability in their roles, and finally, you'll be paired up in teams to solve issues in your community.

Learning to program is the modern day equivalent of having a superpower - it opens up an infinite amount of possibility and opportunity. As our world becomes more technological, people with programming expertise become more and more valuable.   This course is an introduction to basic programming concepts and computational thinking, covering types, control flow, and object-oriented programming. No prior experience is required.
courseTitle: Programming with Python: A Painless Introduction

courseDescription: Want to create a tangible positive impact on your community, but don’t know how to? In this interactive course, you’ll learn how to identify local issues and develop solutions for them, write policy recommendations, lobby public officials for the implementation of your recommendations, and campaign digitally to bolster support for your lobbying efforts. You will receive plenty of detailed and concise resources to help you through the process!
courseTitle: Solving Civic Issues: Policy-Making and Lobbying

courseDescription: In this interactive practice based seminar, students will practice and learn to connect to the universal language of movement to share thoughts and stories. Focusing on site specific dance, dance for social justice, and personal and non personal story telling, students will create movement pieces independently, collaboratively, and with varying amounts of guidance. Students will additionally view and discuss real world examples of story telling through movement and dance for social change. All amounts of experience are welcomed and encouraged to join this class! From two left feet to prima ballerina, any and all movers are welcome as this class will explore hidden abilities to express oneself through movement story telling.

Heard of the infamous Monty Hall problem? Ever wondered why a candidate no one expected to win ended up being the President of the USA? Questioned why scientists could not prevent a major space shuttle catastrophe? In this course, we will give the students an insight into Probability and Statistics and an answer to all these questions! By focusing on Statistics and Statistical Programming, we hope to give the students an idea of both what statistics is and where every statistics project starts. We will investigate the most famous Paradoxes and Riddles in Probability and show the students that Statistics is interesting & fun. Nowadays, with the increasing amount of data available, Statistics allows us to understand every topic much more deeply. Statistics is a crucial part of many discoveries in science and helps with making informed decisions and predictions. No prior coding experience is needed! Please note that you will need a PC to download RStudio.
courseTitle: Introduction to Probability, Statistics, and R Programming Language

courseDescription: Welcome to the world of graphic design! During these sessions, designers will learn how to create eye-catching graphics such as infographics, letters, Instagram posts, and so much more all through the free website Canva! Designers will also learn how to utilize typography and the importance of colors in their designs all while learning how to organize a simple design. Designers will also learn how to collaborate with other designers, build teamwork skills, and create graphics. This session involves many mini projects, along with a final project presentation (with a spin on entrepreneurship!) involving graphics to demonstrate the skills developed in past lessons!

Intro to Mechanics is designed to provide students with a strong physics foundation and, more importantly, a passion for the subject. Through interactive lectures and lab demonstrations, this class introduces two fundamental topics in mechanics: kinematics and dynamics, with an emphasis on conceptual understanding. This class aims to be fun and inspiring; my goal is for each and every student to come away enthusiastic about physics and able to recognize and apply concepts to their everyday experiences.

From the Elven languages of Tolkien to the modern Game of Thrones’ Dothraki, constructed languages are all over the place in modern fantasy and sci-fi. For writers, GMs, and other hobbyists, making a language might sound fascinating, but also close to impossible. Language is so broad, complex, and multilayered that beginning conlangers might have no idea where to start. However, conlanging is not actually as hard as it looks. With this step-by-step course, students can create their own proto-language in five weeks, along with a simple writing system and maybe even a fictional people to use it. This course is for conlanging beginners; no prior experience is necessary, either with conlanging or with linguistics.
courseTitle: Invent Your Own Language: Conlanging for Beginners

courseDescription: How does a quarter of a million dollars sound? Well each year, the Regeneron Science Talent Search gives away a grand prize of $250,000 and many more monetary and prestigious prizes. That winner could be you. Join me in this 5 week journey where we will explore the scientific process, conduct our own research projects, and hone our presentation skills- all culminating in a mock science fair. The world of science fair can open so many doors for you- wether that be a network, college admissions, notarity, or, yes, even money. Science fair has changed my own life- maybe it could change yours too. So together, let's learn HOW TO SCIENCE FAIR!

By the end of Financial Literacy 101, you will know the basics of investing, paying taxes, building good credit, buying a home, and so much more! We will discuss important strategies needed for having a solid and secure financial plan in the future. Knowing how to budget and manage your money is a key life skill to staying out of debt and being financially stress-free.

Do you have an interest in politics? If so, welcome! This workshop will take you on a journey mapping out the rudimentary aspects of a political system ranging from the structural to the intellectual components. We will look at countries like China and the U.S. in order to look at policies in action, analyzing both the intended and unintended consequences. Activities, such as discussions and policy research, will be conducted regularly during the workshop to create an atmosphere of interactivity. For each workshop, policy proposals will be constructed by students as to utilize the knowledge garnered during the lessons.
courseTitle: Political Theory and its Application in Contemporary Society

courseDescription: Do you have an interest in politics? Would you like to construct a foundation within the subject while also studying real-world examples of its practical application? Well, you’ve come to the right place. This class will take you on a journey mapping out the rudimentary aspects of a political system ranging from the basic structures of a government to the diversity of political ideology. We will look at countries like China, the U.K., the U.S., and others that manifest some basic commonalities of governments around the world in conjunction with their own unique aspects. We will also attempt to explore the history and impacts of policies surrounding contemporary issues around elections, education, healthcare, and foreign policy. Each day of instruction will be divided by topical relevance to the basic functions of a government, domestic policy, foreign policy, elections/campaigns, and political ideology. Activities, such as extended discussions guided by thematic questions, will be conducted regularly during the class to create an atmosphere of interactivity and comfortability. In this class, you will also be responsible for creating and presenting a final project on a relevant political issue and proposing a solution to said issue. To give you time in doing so, the last 15-30 minutes of each class day will be allocated for independent work and research on an approved topic. The main goal behind this project and the aforementioned class discussions would be to inspire you to pursue a career in debate, political science, or an associated field that tests your creativity and critical thinking skills. You will be tested on whether you can create both creative and pragmatic solutions to issues our modern world is facing today in the realm of politics. Lastly, this class will also lead you to attaining a broader understanding of the ideologies that drive political discourse today and where they come from within our socioeconomic environments.
courseTitle: Political Theory and its Application in Contemporary Society

courseDescription: Hydroponics is a type of horticulture in which plants are grown with mineral nutrient solutions instead of soil. This course is designed to introduce students to hydroponics and help them gain foundational understandings in this subject. At the end of this course, each student will design their own hydroponics system as their final project.
courseTitle: Play With Hydroponics [Wave x TCSTEM Collab]

Activities, such as discussions and policy research, will be conducted regularly during the workshop to create an atmosphere of interactivity. More and more people have access to a smartphone or computer, with these technologies playing an increasingly important role in the modern world. Those who have used a smartphone, tablet, or computer are also familiar with, and have used apps and websites. Apps, websites, and video games are created with code in order to function, utilizing various programming languages such as Python or Java. In this course, you will be learning the basics of Java and writing code to perform various activities, such as solving math problems and creating mini-games.
courseTitle: Intro to Coding [Wave x TCSTEM Collab]

courseDescription: Learn how to practice Taekwondo through a virtual format. We will go through the basics of the kicks and forms.

So many of you, when we mention India you think of North India. For example the colors, the songs, the dances, and the movies. Who can blame you? But today and over the next few weeks, we will be discussing the underappreciated, gorgeous South India that is enriched with culture. Throughout this course you will travel across the various regions of South India. You will learn everything from traditional clothing, foods, popular movies, and numerous cultures scattered around South India. Sign up for this course to gain a personable understanding of the customs and culture that resides in South India.
courseTitle: A Little Bit of Culture: South Indian Culture and Traditions

Creativity and innovation are two important catalysts which make us more developed civilization at present. This is one of the most vital soft skills that will bring success for you in the long run. But our academic life really hampers our creativity skills. In this workshop, we will learn how to break this chain of behavior with different hands on exercises in the sessions. We will also learn the process of generating and implementing unique ideas through different inspiring stories of creative, innovative and successful people     .

Do you want to start a business? Do you admire a brand or company and wonder how that company works? During this one-time class, learners will dive into the activities of businesses.  They will be exposed to business terminology, concepts, and basic business practices. We will help establish a basic business vocabulary, foster critical and analytical thinking, and look at real-life examples in case studies. After the class, students should be able to tell:  1. What a business is 2. Why there are businesses 3. Goals of businesses 4. Kinds of businesses 5. Basic economic ideas (value, scarcity, opportunity cost, divided labor)    I look forward to seeing you in the class to start your business journey! **All sessions cover the same material.
courseTitle: What is a Business Anyway? Your First Business Education Class Ever!

courseDescription: Have you ever wanted to make a difference in your community but didn't know where to start? Are you looking to be inspired by compelling stories of activism, environmental stewardship, and community engagement? If so, this course is for you! Join us as we take you on a journey to unpack current topics in environmental justice including sustainable food systems, indigenous environmental leadership, urban planning, and environmental education while providing you with the resources to tackle critical issues in your own community.
courseTitle: Current Topics in Environmental Justice: Making a Change in YOUR Community

courseDescription: Proto-Indo-Europeans lived in the late Neolithic period and left very little archaeological evidence. But we do know very specific things about them—their patrilineal society, their focus on animal husbandry, their lack of understanding of silver smelting. How? Their words. No one speaks their language today, but we do have reconstructions of their words based on languages that descended from Proto-Indo-European—languages as diverse as Bengali, Armenian, and English. Archaeology’s not just digging in the dirt. Come explore how old words can be put together to make discoveries, and how regular sound changes can tell us what words people were using thousands of years ago. We will reconstruct ancient words and show how they can be adapted to fit other languages. You'll learn how different languages have different sets of sounds, and how we can use these sounds to plumb the depths of the past. We'll talk about the history of individual words and languages, as well as general patterns of change.

Does .999...=1? Can a sphere be reassembled into two identically sized spheres? Is the consistency of mathematical systems unprovable? Surprisingly, the answer to all of these questions is yes! And at the heart of each question, there lies paradox. For millennia, paradoxes have shaped mathematics and guided mathematical progress. From the ancient paradoxes of Zeno to the modern paradoxes of Russel, paradoxes remind us of the constant need to revamp our mathematical understanding. It is for this reason that paradoxes are so important. Paradoxes: Guiding Forces in Mathematical Exploration ​provides a survey of mathematical paradoxes spanning a wide variety of topics; delving into each paradox mathematically, philosophically, and historically. Students will gain a full picture of how paradoxes have contributed to and guided the progress of mathematics in many ways. This course also provides the student with a robust argument for the inclusion of paradoxes in education. This is all presented in a way that is accessible to anyone with a high school background in mathematics! Entertaining and educational, this course will appeal to any student looking for a mathematical and philosophical challenge.
courseTitle: Paradoxes: Guiding Forces in Mathematical Exploration

courseDescription: Want to create real social change through theatre and performing arts right in your own community? This interactive, game, and discussion-based workshop will serve as an introduction to community theatre-making through a social justice lens. Each class will begin with a community-building activity. The bulk of the class will consist of improv and theatre games, exploration, and practice. Class will end with tangible ways to implement theatre for social justice. Key questions include "What is the arts' role in social movements/activism?", "How can I create art in my own community?", and "What does theatre for social justice look like?"
courseTitle: Theatre and Social Justice in Your Community

courseDescription: Students will be able to see how past science fiction works, such as films or books, have inspired modern technology, as well as how past scientific progress has inspired modern sci-fi media.  Students will also understand the basis of how the real-life side of this technology functions.
courseTitle: The Reality of Science Fiction: How Modern Technology is Following in the Footsteps of Science Fiction
